content:
Nice clash, but it's hard to really see what's happening in-clash with only 4 test cases.

I got 100% on the tests but ended up with 75% on the validators.

Validator 2 is the only test/validator that really checks whether you get the number of charges exactly right.

This was my Ruby code:
d = gets.to_f
t = gets.to_f
x = d/100 + [(d/400).to_i-1,0].max*0.5
puts ["Exactly on time!", "Yes, made it with time left!", "Not enough time!"][t<=>x]

It would be good to add another pair with "Exactly on time!" results, but make sure that the distance isn't a perfect multiple of 400 for the test.

Also, enabling Shortest mode seems fun once this is fixed.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I approve this contribution.
Reverse mode would be fun too.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i think shortest  is good too
Nice, fun clash but I couldn't solve it quite quickly enough to approve it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: More math oriented problem but still a fun one.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Very nitpicky but consider having the test names be a uniform structure, following test 4, for completeness.

Good puzzle, but it's unclear what qualifies as "Just in time!". Does arriving with seconds or minutes to spare qualify? Or does Ulen have to arrive exactly on the buzzer?

Missing test:  0 < (t - (actual journey hours)) < 1

Goal
* Please delete "Standard input:" and also the three lines below that.

* Please change "{{speed}}" to "<<speed>>".

* Please delete "v=".

* Please change "[[time]] given (example t = 12 hours)" to "time given".

* Please change "{{capacity}}" to "<<capacity>>".

* Please change "Charging" to "<<Each charging>>".

* Please format 100, 400 and 30 as {{constants}}.

Input
* Please add "<<Line 1>>: An integer" before "d".

* Please add "in km" after "travel".

* Please add "<<Line 2>>: An integer" before "t".

* Please add "in hours" after "point B".

Output
* Please format the three phrases as {{constants}} instead of in <<bold>>, and remove all the quotation marks.

Variable names
* Please standardise the variable names in Input section, Constraints section and stub generator: use either "d" or "D", use either "t" or "T".

Constraints
* Please format the [[variables]].

Cases
* Test 2 and Validator 2 are the same. Please revise one of them so that they are both similar and different.

Thanks.
Thanks for the feedback, changed every point on your list. Hope it works fine now.

Their is one testcase where you have  0 hours left, I don't know how you could calculte minutes or seconds left. I thought the tests are pretty straight forward. Thanks for your feedback, but I don't think I need to change more.
I don't understand what's wrong with the test names, what do you want them to be?
Can I remake and reenter the same contribution in shortest and reverse clash of codes?
Can I reenter this same contribution in shortest and reverse clash of codes?

Validator 2 is correct, You have to take in account that if you arrive withe 0 time left and an empty battery, you don't need to recharge so your code is not perfect.

Valitator 2: d=2150 km
t=24 hours

Yes, I know. But Validator 2 is the only one that tests for that issue.

Having more tests/validators helps to make sure such edge cases can be debugged in-clash.

That's why I was suggesting adding another pair so that you have a test that is like Validator 2, something like:

Test 5:
3100
34.5
Exactly on time!

Having only 4 pairs makes it hard to debug all issues in-clash.
Agree I will look into that tomorrow
Sounds good. Thanks. It will improve the clash for people I think. :)

I made test 5 with 
3300 km and 
37 hours,
Exactly on time!

Validator 5
3400
38
Exactly on time!
Valid
I cannot use your example because the input is int, not float.
Here is my code in Python3:
d = int(input())
t = int(input())

travel_time = d/100
charges = int(d/400)
battery_left = d-(charges*400)
if battery_left == 0:
    charges -= 1
    
charge_time = charges*0.5
total = travel_time + charge_time

if total < t:
    print("Yes, made it with time left!")
elif total == t:
    print("Exactly on time!")
else:
    print("Not enough time!")
Nice, looks great! Thanks for taking on the suggestion. :)
sure
i don't think reverse is good.... the 30 minutes for charging will not be easy to see
I agree, shortest is possible but this is not an assignment for reverse.

I meant in a hypothetical but not crazy case of (d=99, t=1), Ulen arrives with 36 seconds remaining. If I arrived somewhere with 36 seconds to go, I'd say I got there "Just in time".

It doesn't require any additional test cases, but maybe change "Just in time!" to "Exactly on time!".
Thanks I changed it to "Exactly on time!"
Thank you. As mentioned last time, please add line numbers in <<bold>> before each input description, i.e. "<<Line 1>>:" and "<<Line 2>>:".
Changed the line numbers, sorry I misread it the first time.
